'''NID''' is a [[Primitive Quendian]] [[root]] meaning "press, thrust, force (in a given direction)".<ref name="pe22_165">{{PE|22}}, pg. 165</ref> 

==Development in Primitive Quendian==
From NID was possibly derived '''inidō''', which meant "the mind in its purposing faculty, the will".<ref name="pe22_165" /> This may have been a compound with '''IN''' ("mind", "inner self")<ref name="pe17" />{{rp|155}} and the genitive suffix "-ō". In this origin, inidō would loosely translate to "(the directive) force of the inner self".

Inidō shifted into ''in'dō'', and then ''[[indo]]'' with a verbal form ''indu-''.<ref name="pe22_165" />

==Development in Quenya==
Through the [[Noldorin Quenya]] phonetic development of (d > ř > r),<ref name="pe17">{{PE|17}}</ref>{{rp|129}} NID became the basic verb '''''nír''''' with the same meaning.<ref name="pe22_165" />

Nír had very broad application, and could refer to any type of pressure including physical pressure exerted by or against inanimate objects. In the case of force by a rational will (a faculty of the [[fëa]] and [[Ainur]]), the more specific ''indu-'' was used.<ref name="pe22_165" />

==Development in Sindarin==
In [[Sindarin]] NID shifted phonologically to '''nîð''', and narrowed in meaning to only rational purpose or will.<ref name="pe22_165" />

''Indu'' shifted phonologically (indu > ind > inn), and ''inn'' came to mean some ''particular'' purpose or intention of an individual.<ref name="pe22_165" />

==Development in Telerin==
In [[Telerin]] ''nīde'' had the same meaning as S. ''nîð'', and ''indo'' had the same meaning as S. ''inn''. The verb ''nid-'' had the same meaning as Q. ''nir''.<ref name="pe22_165" />
